examples: Anyway, the point is, my first pash — or snog, or whatever you want to call it — was so bloody awful it’s a miracle I ever opened my mouth again.

‘It isn’t a pash. Nancy Burke’s got a pash on Mr Richards and Mary Parkin has a pash on Miss Taylor, and so have other girls. But I haven’t got a pash on Rupert. It isn’t like that. I know it isn’t. I know it isn’t.’

entries.meaning: The object of a romantic infatuation; a crush.

verbs.description: pash (third-person singular simple present pashes, present participle pashing, simple past and past participle pashed)

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) To snog, to make out, to kiss.
examples: There are hundreds of different types of kisses; and there are kissing Kamasutras available in bookshops to help you add variety to your pashing repertoire.

description: Scots word for the pate, or head.

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect, obsolete) A heavy fall of rain or snow.

description: Probably of imitative origin, or possibly akin to box (“to fight with the fists”).

verbs.description: pash (third-person singular simple present pashes, present participle pashing, simple past and past participle pashed)

entries.meaning: (dialect) To throw (or be thrown) and break.
To strike; to crush; to smash; to dash into pieces.
examples: [...] 'tis a brute must walk / Pashing their life out, with a brute's intents.
